description: From North Levantine Arabic مختار‎ (“village headman”), from substantive application of Arabic مُخْتَار‎ (muḵtār, “chosen”), the passive participle of اِخْتَارَ‎ (iḵtāra, “to elect, to choose”). Specific application with influence from various local languages including Ottoman Turkish مختار‎ (muhtar, “village headman”) and Bengali মুখতার (mukhtar), Marathi मुख्तार (mukhtār), and Urdu مختار‎ (muktār, “agent; lawyer”). Within Indian English, the application of mukhtar is influenced by a folk etymology derivation from Sanskrit मुक्ति (mukti, “liberation, becoming or setting free”). Doublet of myftar.

definitionGroups.group: (politics) A minor official—usually overseeing a village or town—in many Arab countries and (historical) in the Ottoman Empire and its successor states, including Turkey, Northern Cyprus, and formerly Albania.

entries.meaning: (specifically) Alternative spelling of muhtar: an elected official overseeing a village or neighborhood in modern Turkey.
(India, historical) A person acting as an agent, particularly a lawyer. [early 19th – mid 20th c.]
